DataElement.preferredName: Stomach Neoplasm Anatomic And Anatomy Qualifier Subsite Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to describe the sub-division of the stomach for an individual with cancer.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The organ located between the esophagus and the small intestine where digestion of food occurs before passing to the small intestine._A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The organ located between the esophagus and the small intestine where digestion of food occurs before passing to the small intestine.:(NEE-o-PLAY-zha) Abnormal and uncontrolled cell growth.

Concepts.definition: The primary organ of food digestion. It is located under the diaphragm, between the liver and the spleen as well as between the esophagus and the small intestine.

A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.

Property.preferredDefinition: A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated for The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) by request of S. Ratliff (JP) 3/2011.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The organ located between the esophagus and the small intestine where digestion of food occurs before passing to the small intestine._Relating to anatomy._An article which expresses the relation of connection or addition. It is used to conjoin a word with a word, a clause with a clause, or a sentence with a sentence._An adjectival term used to specify a region of the body or other concepts associated with the body._A position within another named site._The words or language units by which a thing is known

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Distal; situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline or mesial plane of the body.: The initial part of the pyloric canal of the stomach.  This site contains endocrine cells that produce gastrin and somatostatin.

Concepts.definition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.
The initial part of the pyloric canal of the stomach. This site contains endocrine cells that produce gastrin and somatostatin.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The larger part of a hollow organ that is farthest away from the organ's opening. The bladder, gallbladder, stomach, uterus, eye, and cavity of the middle ear all have a fundus.: Relating to the stomach.

Concepts.definition: The bottom portion or the portion that is furthest from the opening of a hollow organ.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Proximal; situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.: The area around the esophagogastric mucosal junction where the esophageal mucosa transitions into the gastric mucosa.

Concepts.definition: Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.
The area around the esophagogastric mucosal junction where the esophageal mucosa transitions into the gastric mucosa.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The anatomical location where the esophagus joins to the stomach.

Concepts.definition: The anatomical location where the esophagus joins to the stomach.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: locations or structures in the human body.
